content.question: Let y = f (x) be a twice-differentiable function such that f (1) = 2 and <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <mi>d</mi><mi>y</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>d</mi><mi>x</mi> </mrow> </mfrac> <mo>=</mo><msup> <mi>y</mi> <mn>3</mn> </msup> <mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3EE5@</annotation> </semantics> </math>. What is the value of <math> <semantics> <mrow> <mfrac> <mrow> <msup> <mi>d</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> <mi>y</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>d</mi><msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </mrow> </mfrac> </mrow> <annotation encoding="MathType-MTEF">MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3C49@</annotation> </semantics> </math> at x = 1 ?

unit.text: 3: Differentiation: Composite, Implicit, and Inverse Functions
